Disaster aid talks collapse as Congress heads for recess
By CAITLIN EMMA and MARIANNE LEVINE
Share on Facebook Share on Twitter
Senate negotiations over a disaster relief package have broken down, all
but ensuring that Puerto Rico and states stricken by storms, wildfires and
flooding will be left waiting for emergency aid until after Congress
Democrats have rejected the latest offer made by Republican appropriators
over funding for Puerto Rico, according to three sources familiar with the
The collapse in negotiations comes after the Senate last week shot down
two competing plans that would provide at least $13 billion in aid to
communities hit by hurricanes, wildfires and catastrophic flooding in
recent months. It’s unclear what Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell
will decide to do now with the stalled bill.
Congressional action on emergency aid has been held up since December, due
in large part to President Donald Trump’s unsubstantiated claims that
Puerto Rico shouldn’t receive any more money because its politicians have
mismanaged federal funds. Lawmakers are now scheduled to gavel out for two
Both Republicans and Democrats have agreed on providing about $600 million
in nutrition assistance for Puerto Rico, in addition to funding for
Midwestern states damaged by flooding this year.
But Democrats have insisted on more federal funding for Puerto Rico, in
addition to language that frees up billions of Community Development Block
Grant funds for the island. HUD Secretary Ben Carson, whose agency manages
the funds, said last week that reports of the White House trying to block
or slow-walk the funds are “completely inaccurate.”
